sn35.54:1.1.pli: “Kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato, kathaṃ passato, saṃyojanā pahīyantī”ti?
sn35.54:1.1.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the fetters are given up?”
sn35.54:1.1.comm: The five lower (SN 45.179) and higher (SN 45.180) fetters.

sn35.54:1.2.pli: “Cakkhuṃ kho, bhikkhu, aniccato jānato passato saṃyojanā pahīyanti.
sn35.54:1.2.eng: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye as impermanent, the fetters are given up …”

sn35.54:1.6.pli: yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccato jānato passato saṃyojanā pahīyanti.

sn35.54:1.15.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccato jānato passato saṃyojanā pahīyanti.

sn35.54:1.16.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, jānato evaṃ passato saṃyojanā pahīyantī”ti.

sn35.55:1.1.pli: “Kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato, kathaṃ passato saṃyojanā samugghātaṃ gacchantī”ti?
sn35.55:1.1.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the fetters are uprooted?”

sn35.55:1.2.pli: “Cakkhuṃ kho, bhikkhu, anattato jānato passato saṃyojanā samugghātaṃ gacchanti.
sn35.55:1.2.eng: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye as not-self, the fetters are uprooted …”
sn35.55:1.2.comm: Throughout this section, only anicca and anattā are mentioned. Parallel passages with dukkha may have been lost to abbreviation. Each of the characteristics includes the others, but they are taught according to the inclination of the meditator.

sn35.55:1.6.pli: yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anattato jānato passato saṃyojanā samugghātaṃ gacchanti.

sn35.55:1.15.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anattato jānato passato saṃyojanā samugghātaṃ gacchanti.

sn35.55:1.16.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, jānato evaṃ passato saṃyojanā samugghātaṃ gacchantī”ti.

sn35.56:1.1.pli: “Kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato, kathaṃ passato āsavā pahīyantī”ti …pe….
sn35.56:1.1.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the defilements are given up?” …
sn35.56:1.1.comm: The “defilements” (āsava) are listed at SN 45.163.

sn35.57:1.1.pli: “Kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato, kathaṃ passato āsavā samugghātaṃ gacchantī”ti …pe….
sn35.57:1.1.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the defilements are uprooted?” …

sn35.58:1.1.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the underlying tendencies are given up?” …
sn35.58:1.1.comm: The “underlying tendencies” (anusaya) are enumerated at SN 45.175.

sn35.59:1.1.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the underlying tendencies are uprooted?” …

sn35.59:1.3.pli: “Cakkhuṃ kho, bhikkhu, anattato jānato passato anusayā samugghātaṃ gacchanti …pe…

sn35.59:1.12.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anattato jānato passato anusayā samugghātaṃ gacchanti.

sn35.59:1.13.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, jānato evaṃ passato anusayā samugghātaṃ gacchantī”ti.

sn35.6:1.2.pli: Yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
sn35.6:1.2.eng: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ …”

sn35.6:1.8.pli: Yadanattā taṃ ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.

sn35.60:0.3.eng: The Complete Understanding of All Grasping

sn35.60:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the principle for the complete understanding of all grasping.
sn35.60:1.1.comm: The four kinds of grasping are listed at SN 12.2:6.3.

sn35.60:1.3.eng: And what is the principle for the complete understanding of all grasping?

sn35.60:1.4.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.60:1.4.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.60:1.5.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.60:1.6.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati, rūpesupi nibbindati, cakkhuviññāṇepi nibbindati, cakkhusamphassepi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati.
sn35.60:1.6.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and feeling.

sn35.60:1.7.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimokkhā ‘pariññātaṃ me upādānan’ti pajānāti.
sn35.60:1.7.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they are liberated, they understand: ‘I have completely understood grasping.’

sn35.60:1.8.eng: Ear consciousness arises dependent on the ear and sounds. …

sn35.60:1.9.eng: Nose consciousness arises dependent on the nose and smells. …

sn35.60:1.10.eng: Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes. …

sn35.60:1.11.eng: Body consciousness arises dependent on the body and touches. …

sn35.60:1.12.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.60:1.12.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.60:1.13.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.60:1.14.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako manasmimpi nibbindati, dhammesupi nibbindati, manoviññāṇepi nibbindati, manosamphassepi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati.
sn35.60:1.14.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the mind, ideas, mind consciousness, mind contact, and feeling.

sn35.60:1.15.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimokkhā ‘pariññātaṃ me upādānan’ti pajānāti.
sn35.60:1.15.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they are liberated, they understand: ‘I have completely understood grasping.’

sn35.60:1.16.eng: This is the principle for the complete understanding of all grasping.”

sn35.61:0.3.eng: The Depletion of All Fuel for Grasping (1st)

sn35.61:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the principle for depleting all fuel for grasping.
sn35.61:1.1.comm: Upādāna has the primary meaning of “grasping”, and secondarily “fuel” (SN 12.52). Here the usage with pariyādāna (“depletion”) shows the metaphor of “fuel” is active; you can’t “deplete grasping”.

sn35.61:1.3.eng: And what is the principle for depleting all fuel for grasping?

sn35.61:1.4.pli: Cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.61:1.4.eng: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.61:1.5.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.61:1.6.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati, rūpesupi nibbindati, cakkhuviññāṇepi nibbindati, cakkhusamphassepi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati.
sn35.61:1.6.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and feeling.

sn35.61:1.7.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimokkhā ‘pariyādinnaṃ me upādānan’ti pajānāti …pe…
sn35.61:1.7.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they are liberated, they understand: ‘I have completely depleted fuel for grasping.’

sn35.61:1.8.pli: jivhañca paṭicca rase ca uppajjati jivhāviññāṇaṃ …pe…

sn35.61:1.9.pli: manañca paṭicca dhamme ca uppajjati manoviññāṇaṃ. Tiṇṇaṃ saṅgati phasso.
sn35.61:1.9.eng: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and ideas. The meeting of the three is contact.

sn35.61:1.10.eng: Contact is a requirement for feeling.

sn35.61:1.11.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako manasmimpi nibbindati, dhammesupi nibbindati, manoviññāṇepi nibbindati manosamphassepi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati.
sn35.61:1.11.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the mind, ideas, mind consciousness, mind contact, and feeling.

sn35.61:1.12.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimokkhā ‘pariyādinnaṃ me upādānan’ti pajānāti.
sn35.61:1.12.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they are liberated, they understand: ‘I have completely depleted fuel for grasping.’

sn35.61:1.13.eng: This is the principle for depleting all fuel for grasping.”

sn35.62:0.3.eng: The Depletion of All Fuel for Grasping (2nd)

sn35.62:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the principle for depleting all fuel for grasping.

sn35.62:1.3.eng: And what is the principle for depleting all fuel for grasping?

sn35.62:2.2.eng: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.62:4.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.62:4.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.62:6.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn35.62:6.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.62:6.2.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.62:12.1.pli: “Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.62:12.1.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.62:14.9.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā, tampi niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.62:14.9.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”

sn35.62:16.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.62:16.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn35.62:18.1.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn35.62:18.1.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn35.62:18.2.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn35.62:20.1.pli: “Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako cakkhusmimpi nibbindati, rūpesupi nibbindati, cakkhuviññāṇepi nibbindati, cakkhusamphassepi nibbindati.
sn35.62:20.1.eng: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact.

sn35.62:20.2.pli: Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tasmimpi nibbindati …pe…
sn35.62:20.2.eng: And they grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact.

sn35.62:20.3.pli: jivhāyapi nibbindati, rasesupi nibbindati, jivhāviññāṇepi nibbindati, jivhāsamphassepi nibbindati, yampidaṃ jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati …pe…
sn35.62:20.3.eng: They grow disillusioned with the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.62:20.4.pli: manasmimpi nibbindati, dhammesupi nibbindati, manoviññāṇepi nibbindati, manosamphassepi nibbindati.
sn35.62:20.4.eng: They grow disillusioned with the mind, ideas, mind consciousness, and mind contact.

sn35.62:20.5.pli: Yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tasmimpi nibbindati.
sn35.62:20.5.eng: And they grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact.

sn35.62:20.6.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati; vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn35.62:20.6.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn35.62:20.7.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
sn35.62:20.7.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

sn35.62:20.8.eng: This is the principle for depleting all fuel for grasping.”

sn35.63:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā migajālo yena bhagavā …pe…
sn35.63:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Migajāla went up to the Buddha …

sn35.63:1.3.pli: ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā migajālo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

sn35.63:1.4.eng: “Sir, they speak of one who lives alone.
sn35.63:1.4.comm: “One who lives alone” (ekavihārī) is also mentioned at SN 21.10:1.5 and Thag 10.2.

sn35.63:1.5.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, ekavihārī hoti, kittāvatā ca pana sadutiyavihārī hotī”ti?
sn35.63:1.5.eng: How is one who lives alone defined? And how is living with a partner defined?”
sn35.63:1.5.comm: “Partner” is dutiya (“second”), a companion or spouse.

sn35.63:2.1.pli: “Santi kho, migajāla, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.63:2.1.eng: “Migajāla, there are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.63:2.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn35.63:2.2.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,

sn35.63:2.3.pli: Tassa taṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato uppajjati nandī.

sn35.63:2.5.eng: When there’s lust there is yoking.

sn35.63:2.6.pli: Nandisaṃyojanasaṃyutto kho, migajāla, bhikkhu sadutiyavihārīti vuccati.
sn35.63:2.6.eng: A mendicant who is fettered by relishing is said to live with a partner.

sn35.63:2.7.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.63:2.8.pli: Santi kho, migajāla, jivhāviññeyyā rasā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.63:2.8.eng: There are ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
sn35.63:2.8.comm: MS omits mano here in error. It is included in the following round in this Sutta, and in both rounds of the next Sutta. Mano is found in the PTS and BJT editions, which I follow here.

sn35.63:2.9.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn35.63:2.9.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,

sn35.63:2.10.pli: Tassa taṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato uppajjati nandī.

sn35.63:2.12.eng: When there’s lust there is yoking.

sn35.63:2.13.pli: Nandisaṃyojanasaṃyutto kho, migajāla, bhikkhu sadutiyavihārīti vuccati.
sn35.63:2.13.eng: A mendicant who is fettered by relishing is said to live with a partner.

sn35.63:2.14.pli: Evaṃvihārī ca, migajāla, bhikkhu kiñcāpi araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevati appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni;
sn35.63:2.14.eng: A mendicant who lives like this is said to live with a partner, even if they frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat.

sn35.63:2.17.eng: For craving is their partner, and they haven’t given it up.

sn35.63:2.18.eng: That’s why they’re said to live with a partner.

sn35.63:3.1.pli: Santi ca kho, migajāla, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.63:3.1.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.63:3.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn35.63:3.2.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them,

sn35.63:3.3.pli: Tassa taṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato nandī nirujjhati.

sn35.63:3.4.eng: When there’s no relishing there’s no lust.

sn35.63:3.5.eng: When there’s no lust there’s no yoking.

sn35.63:3.6.pli: Nandisaṃyojanavisaṃyutto kho, migajāla, bhikkhu ekavihārīti vuccati …pe…
sn35.63:3.6.eng: A mendicant who is not fettered by relishing is said to live alone.

sn35.63:3.7.pli: santi ca kho, migajāla, jivhāviññeyyā rasā …pe…
sn35.63:3.7.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.63:3.8.pli: santi ca kho, migajāla, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.63:3.8.eng: There are ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.63:3.9.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn35.63:3.9.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them,

sn35.63:3.10.pli: Tassa taṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato nandī nirujjhati.

sn35.63:3.11.eng: When there’s no relishing there’s no lust.

sn35.63:3.12.eng: When there’s no lust there’s no yoking.

sn35.63:3.13.pli: Nandisaṃyojanavippayutto kho, migajāla, bhikkhu ekavihārīti vuccati.
sn35.63:3.13.eng: A mendicant who is not fettered by relishing is said to live alone.

sn35.63:3.14.pli: Evaṃvihārī ca, migajāla, bhikkhu kiñcāpi gāmante viharati ākiṇṇo bhikkhūhi bhikkhunīhi upāsakehi upāsikāhi rājūhi rājamahāmattehi titthiyehi titthiyasāvakehi.
sn35.63:3.14.eng: A mendicant who lives like this is said to live alone, even if they live within a village crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their chief ministers, and monastics of other religions and their disciples.

sn35.63:3.17.eng: For craving is their partner, and they have given it up.

sn35.63:3.18.eng: That’s why they’re said to live alone.”

sn35.64:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā migajālo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe…
sn35.64:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Migajāla went up to the Buddha …

sn35.64:1.2.pli: ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā migajālo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

sn35.64:1.3.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn35.64:1.3.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
sn35.64:1.3.comm: Despite the Buddha’s reservations in the previous discourse, it is normal for mendicants to withdraw into retreat for dedicated practice. Here, it seems, Migajāla determines to practice living alone in both ways, as he was taught in the previous Sutta.

sn35.64:2.1.pli: “Santi kho, migajāla, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.64:2.1.eng: “Migajāla, there are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.64:2.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn35.64:2.2.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,

sn35.64:2.3.pli: Tassa taṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato uppajjati nandī.

sn35.64:2.4.eng: Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.

sn35.64:2.5.pli: santi ca kho, migajāla, jivhāviññeyyā rasā …pe…
sn35.64:2.5.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.64:2.6.pli: santi ca kho, migajāla, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.64:2.6.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.64:2.7.pli: Tañce bhikkhu abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
sn35.64:2.7.eng: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keeps clinging to them,

sn35.64:2.8.pli: Tassa taṃ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato uppajjati nandī.

sn35.64:2.9.eng: Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.

sn35.64:3.1.pli: Santi ca kho, migajāla, cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.64:3.1.eng: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.64:3.2.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati. Tassa taṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato nandī nirujjhati.
sn35.64:3.2.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, relishing ceases.

sn35.64:3.3.eng: When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say.

sn35.64:3.4.pli: santi ca kho, migajāla, jivhāviññeyyā rasā iṭṭhā kantā …pe…
sn35.64:3.4.eng: There are sounds … smells … tastes … touches …

sn35.64:3.5.pli: santi ca kho, migajāla, manoviññeyyā dhammā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn35.64:3.5.eng: ideas known by the mind, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn35.64:3.6.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nābhinandati nābhivadati nājjhosāya tiṭṭhati. Tassa taṃ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato nandī nirujjhati.
sn35.64:3.6.eng: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, relishing ceases.

sn35.64:3.7.eng: When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say.”

sn35.64:4.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā migajālo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
sn35.64:4.1.eng: And then Venerable Migajāla approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

sn35.64:4.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā migajālo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharato nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
sn35.64:4.2.eng: Then Migajāla, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

sn35.64:4.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
sn35.64:4.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

sn35.64:4.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā migajālo arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn35.64:4.4.eng: And Migajāla became one of the perfected.

sn35.65:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn35.65:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn35.65:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā samiddhi yena bhagavā …pe…
sn35.65:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Samiddhi went up to the Buddha …
sn35.65:1.2.comm: For Samiddhi, see note on SN 1.20:1.3.

sn35.65:1.4.eng: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘Māra’.

sn35.65:1.5.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, māro vā assa mārapaññatti vā”ti?
sn35.65:1.5.eng: How do we define Māra or what is known as Māra?”
sn35.65:1.5.comm: This phrasing is distinctive of this series of discourses (up to SN 35.68).

sn35.65:2.1.pli: “Yattha kho, samiddhi, atthi cakkhu, atthi rūpā, atthi cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, atthi cakkhuviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā, atthi tattha māro vā mārapaññatti vā.
sn35.65:2.1.eng: “Samiddhi, where there is the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and things knowable by eye consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.

sn35.65:2.2.pli: Atthi sotaṃ, atthi saddā, atthi sotaviññāṇaṃ, atthi sotaviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā, atthi tattha māro vā mārapaññatti vā.
sn35.65:2.2.eng: Where there is the ear, sounds, ear consciousness, and things knowable by ear consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.

sn35.65:2.3.pli: Atthi ghānaṃ, atthi gandhā, atthi ghānaviññāṇaṃ, atthi ghānaviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā, atthi tattha māro vā mārapaññatti vā.
sn35.65:2.3.eng: Where there is the nose, smells, nose consciousness, and things knowable by nose consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.

sn35.65:2.4.pli: Atthi jivhā, atthi rasā, atthi jivhāviññāṇaṃ, atthi jivhāviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā, atthi tattha māro vā mārapaññatti vā.
sn35.65:2.4.eng: Where there is the tongue, tastes, tongue consciousness, and things knowable by tongue consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.

sn35.65:2.5.pli: Atthi kāyo, atthi phoṭṭhabbā, atthi kāyaviññāṇaṃ, atthi kāyaviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā, atthi tattha māro vā mārapaññatti vā.
sn35.65:2.5.eng: Where there is the body, touches, body consciousness, and things knowable by body consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.

sn35.65:2.6.pli: Atthi mano, atthi dhammā, atthi manoviññāṇaṃ, atthi manoviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā, atthi tattha māro vā mārapaññatti vā.
sn35.65:2.6.eng: Where there is the mind, ideas, mind consciousness, and things knowable by mind consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.

sn35.65:3.1.pli: Yattha ca kho, samiddhi, natthi cakkhu, natthi rūpā, natthi cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, natthi cakkhuviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā, natthi tattha māro vā mārapaññatti vā.
sn35.65:3.1.eng: Where there is no eye, no sights, no eye consciousness, and no things knowable by eye consciousness, there is no Māra or what is known as Māra.

sn35.65:3.4.pli: natthi jivhā, natthi rasā, natthi jivhāviññāṇaṃ, natthi jivhāviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā, natthi tattha māro vā mārapaññatti vā.

sn35.65:3.6.pli: Natthi mano, natthi dhammā, natthi manoviññāṇaṃ, natthi manoviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā, natthi tattha māro vā mārapaññatti vā”ti.
sn35.65:3.6.eng: Where there is no mind, no ideas, no mind consciousness, and no things knowable by mind consciousness, there is no Māra or what is known as Māra.”

sn35.66:0.3.eng: Samiddhi’s Question About a Sentient Being

sn35.66:1.1.eng: “Sir, they speak of this thing called a ‘sentient being’.

sn35.66:1.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, satto vā assa sattapaññatti vā”ti …pe….
sn35.66:1.2.eng: How do we define a sentient being or what is known as a sentient being?” …

sn35.67:1.1.eng: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘suffering’.

sn35.67:1.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, dukkhaṃ vā assa dukkhapaññatti vā”ti …pe….
sn35.67:1.2.eng: How do we define suffering or what is known as suffering?” …

sn35.68:1.1.eng: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘the world’.

sn35.68:1.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, loko vā assa lokapaññatti vā”ti?
sn35.68:1.2.eng: How do we define the world or what is known as the world?”
sn35.68:1.2.comm: The parallel at SA 230 has, “As for the world, why is it called the world?” (世間者，云何名世.

sn35.68:1.3.pli: “Yattha kho, samiddhi, atthi cakkhu, atthi rūpā, atthi cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, atthi cakkhuviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā, atthi tattha loko vā lokapaññatti vāti …pe…
sn35.68:1.3.eng: “Samiddhi, where there is the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and things knowable by eye consciousness, there is the world or what is known as the world.

sn35.68:1.4.eng: Where there is the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.68:1.5.pli: atthi mano, atthi dhammā, atthi manoviññāṇaṃ, atthi manoviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā, atthi tattha loko vā lokapaññatti vā.
sn35.68:1.5.eng: Where there is the mind, ideas, mind consciousness, and things knowable by mind consciousness, there is the world or what is known as the world.

sn35.68:2.1.pli: Yattha ca kho, samiddhi, natthi cakkhu, natthi rūpā, natthi cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, natthi cakkhuviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā, natthi tattha loko vā lokapaññatti vā …pe…
sn35.68:2.1.eng: Where there is no eye, no sights, no eye consciousness, and no things knowable by eye consciousness, there is no world or what is known as the world.

sn35.68:2.2.eng: Where there is no ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.68:2.3.pli: natthi mano, natthi dhammā, natthi manoviññāṇaṃ, natthi manoviññāṇaviññātabbā dhammā, natthi tattha loko vā lokapaññatti vā”ti.
sn35.68:2.3.eng: Where there is no mind, no ideas, no mind consciousness, and no things knowable by mind consciousness, there is no world or what is known as the world.”
